content: I'm working with Stephen Wolfram to add tetration, hyperoperators and infinite power towers to Mathematica Functions. Before I can do that I need to publish my work. After fifty years of lone research, I'm now working with others and it is really improving the quality of my work. I just learned about the politics of convergence proofs from Yiannis Galidakis who alerted me about it in analytic continuation. People don't want to see innovative convergence proofs, they want to deal with convergence proofs like they have dealt with before and that means analytic continuation. My recent good news is functional equation are usually used in analytic continuation and I know the functional equations that describe the continuations.

I've been plodding along on the project to index This Weeks Finds due to personal issues and the difficulty of the problem.

  1. Index the ASCII version for simplicity's sake.
  2. Language for text parsing - Perl, Mathematica, ect.
  3. Difficulty indexing phrases like "4-dimensional topological quantum field theory."
  4. Approaches
  • Pure automation
  • Custom GUI to facilitate human editing
  • Combination of automation and GUI
  • Support for massive editing by a number of people
It's possible this is not a great use of your time!

@John Baez I strongly believe in doing social service. I support intellectually and politically both you and this forum. But my professional background is in software development and it is where I'm currently most effective. While I do math, I need to multitask in order to keep my mind supple.
Great! But it could be that some other project is a better use of your time.
It depends a lot on how hard it turns out to be to create an index!

I'm making enough progress indexing TWF that collective issues are arising. I'm reporting in so that folks have time to provide feedback on where the project is going.

Indexing on the cheap
Compared to statically indexing TWF, Google provides relevance based indexing.
Google index for gravity on TWF site and use " site:math.ucr.edu/home/baez gravity". The TWF contains the word "gravity" 1420 times, which is not common in the English language. Using an API for Google and Wikipedia could be helpful.

A home for the index
I could host the index with my resources, but that might not be appropriate. A nice index would be a work in process, so it would be best if I had edit rights.

Additive and subtractive editing
Indexing the TWF is easy; backing frequently used words out takes more work. I currently am using a list of the one hundred most common English words. The first three hundred TWF are comprised of 37775 different words (including things like digits and URLs).

Mathematica
I'm able to do much of the heavy lifting with a relatively few lines of Mathematica. Text analysis and word clouds are supported by Mathematica although my computer with 12G RAM struggles with medium size word clouds.

Bn,kB_{n,k}Bn,k​ is a partial Bell polynomial.

dndxnf(g(x))=∑k=1nf(k)(g(x))⋅Bn,k(g′(x),g′′(x),…,g(n−k+1)(x)).{d^n \over dx^n} f(g(x)) = \sum_{k=1}^n f^{(k)}(g(x))\cdot B_{n,k}\left(g'(x),g''(x),\dots,g^{(n-k+1)}(x)\right).dxndn​f(g(x))=∑k=1n​f(k)(g(x))⋅Bn,k​(g′(x),g′′(x),…,g(n−k+1)(x)).

Set g(x)=ft−1(x)g(x)=f^{t-1}(x)g(x)=ft−1(x)

dndxnft(x)=∑k=1nf(k)(ft−1(x))⋅Bn,k(ddxft−1(x),d2dx2ft−1(x),…,dn−k+1dxn−k+1ft−1(x)).\begin{align} {d^n \over dx^n} f^t(x) = \sum_{k=1}^n & f^{(k)}(f^{t-1}(x)) \nonumber \\ & \cdot B_{n,k}\left({d \over dx}f^{t-1}(x),{d^2 \over dx^2}f^{t-1}(x),\dots,{d^{n-k+1} \over dx^{n-k+1}}f^{t-1}(x)\right). \nonumber \end{align}dxndn​ft(x)=k=1∑n​​f(k)(ft−1(x))⋅Bn,k​(dxd​ft−1(x),dx2d2​ft−1(x),…,dxn−k+1dn−k+1​ft−1(x)).​

When seen as the derivatives of a dynamical system, the complexity of the behaviors that can be displayed is vast. I want to make it more understandable by using the preceding identity to easily derive the underlying combinatoric structures P,S,K,\mathcal{P},\mathcal{S},\mathcal{K},P,S,K, and L\mathcal{L}L. Ideally the would provide a way to model and solve dynamical systems using much simpler combinatorics.

The following makes the assumption of the existence of a fixed point. By computer algebra the derivative dndxnft(x){d^n \over dx^n} f^t(x)dxndn​ft(x) has K[n]\mathcal{K}[n]K[n] additive terms while the sum of the coefficients of the additive terms is L[n]\mathcal{L}[n]L[n]. Since L[n]\mathcal{L}[n]L[n] grows far more quickly than K[n]\mathcal{K}[n]K[n], efficient computer algebra must use K[n]\mathcal{K}[n]K[n] instead of L[n]\mathcal{L}[n]L[n].
Hi @Daniel Geisler, I changed the title of this topic to reflect the praxis of this stream (you did nothing wrong)
Also, have you seen this and this on the Faà di Bruno construction?
Thank you @Matteo Capucci (he/him), Five interpretations of Faà di Bruno’s formula is also an ArXiv paper. I have many questions I expect this paper to answer.

The most useful thing I've done lately is working with the machine learning of mathematics. I have become more proficient with the technology as it rapidly improves. I have returned to working on indexing TWF, but now it is coming together quick enough that I need to work out details like how the index should be formatted.

I'm interested in people's thoughts on what a more advanced index would support beyond TWFs. There are great resources like this forum, nLab and Arxiv.

I've just seen there is written "Faà di Bruno's formula" here.

I'm a big fan of the Faà di Bruno's formula! I think it will play a big role in my Phd thesis. My first research work has been to define a notion of "graded" differential category (differential categories have been defined by Cockett and co., the same Cockett as the author of the paper linked above) and a bit later in a second work (still to be written cleanly), I used the Faà di Bruno's formula to prove a theorem about differential categories (this theorem extracts a graded differential category out of every non too crazy differential category).

The essence of how I'm using the Faà di Bruno's formula is through this "fact" which it implies: in "differential algebra" (this kind of differential algebra, with composition of differentiable functions, require differential categories! in classical differential algebra you don't have this ability to compose. in a way, differential categories are just differential algebra with composition :)) if f(n)=0f^{(n)}=0f(n)=0 and g(p)=0g^{(p)}=0g(p)=0, then (f∘g)(np)=0(f \circ g)^{(np)}=0(f∘g)(np)=0.
It's similar to how the degrees of polynomials multiply when you compose them.
Probably you don't care about all this and 80% of what I wrote is quite obscure but it was just to say that this formula is important to me :)
@Jean-Baptiste Vienney, don't sell yourself short, I find your work interesting. :smile:
